Yeah, basically what the story is, and it's a story that I pretty much stumbled upon in Iraq when I was in Diwaniyah, and I met some kind of insurgency specialist who worked for General Patreaus, investigates the following question.

We had such few forces in that part of Iraq and the tribes wanted them out and they wanted control over the situation.
So there is a kind of a rough parallel.
And what's sort of interesting is that there has been some dialogue between the Shiite tribes in the south and the Sunni tribes in Anbar.
Shiite sheiks would go to Anbar for sort of - to get the lessons learned, so to speak, of how the Sunni tribes had aligned themselves with the Americans to fight al-Qaeda.
What can you get out of the Americans?

On the other hand, the American government wants Maliki to succeed and to be a strong figure and to certainly have command over the security situation through the Iraqi security forces.
So the American government was pretty much caught in the middle.
But when push came to shove, it sided with Maliki on this one.
